subject: Re: junit 4 expected= subclass change
msgSnippet: ... there ... so ... clauses ... precise ... works. ... allowed ... You can throw *new* types of exceptions in reaction to new types of behavior in different
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Ben Maurer wrote:
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" kentb@ wrote:
> > >
> > > Ben,
> > >
> > > Thank you for the feedback. We went around on this. It seems
there
> > are two
> > > cases:
> > >
> > > 1) I am throwing an exception but I want to make it more specific
so
> > I throw
> > > a subclass (Exception -> IllegalArgumentException). No catch
clauses
> > care
> > > about the more-specific exception. If expected is looking for a
precise
> > > class, a bunch of tests will break even though the code still
works.
> >
> > I've never seen an api that says "when you do X, we will throw a
> > random type of exception (though it will derive from Y)"
>
> I hope you have! The Liskov Substitution Principle says that I'm
allowed
> to throw an exception I want, as long as it is an instanceof the one I
> declare I'm going to throw. This is why I don't like possibly throwing
> different exceptions in each other's inheritance tree. (I don't treat
> RuntimeException as an instanceof Exception for the purposes of this
> line of reasoning. To me, that was a heinous mistake on Java's part.
> They should each extend Throwable or some other common base class.)

You can throw *new* types of exceptions in reaction to new types of
behavior in different versions. However, the *exact* same action should
result in the *exact* same type of exception.

-- Ben
